properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR BURNS LAKE March 16, 2021 14:00 - Smithers) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Burns Lake because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes, respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-18T07:06:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-17T15:07:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1388931297.2021
Area: Lakes District
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall and wind expected Thursday night and Friday. Total rainfall amounts: 30 to 50 mm. Maximum wind gusts: southerly between 80 and 100 km/h. Locations: The Avalon Peninsula. Time span: Thursday evening to Friday evening. Remarks: Rain will begin Thursday evening and become heavy at times on Friday. Strong southerly winds will accompany the rain, combining with temperatures well above freezing to cause considerable snow melt. If possible, storm drains should be cleared before Thursday night, as a combination of rain, snow melt, and runoff will likely lead to minor flooding in areas where pooling water cannot drain properly. Rain will change to snow Friday evening with a period of freezing rain or ice pellets possible during the transition. Note that as temperatures fall below freezing Friday night, conditions will likely become quite icy. Conditions will improve overnight Friday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-18T05:33:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-17T13:34:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0479549859.2021
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected on Friday. Total snowfall: 10 cm with 15 cm or more possible over eastern Nova Scotia. Location: most of Nova Scotia. Remarks: Rain will change to snow early Friday morning then taper off Friday afternoon. The highest accumulations will be over eastern Nova Scotia. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-18T06:09:45-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain expected Thursday night then potential for significant snow on Friday. Total snowfall: 10 to 25 cm. Locations: southern, northeastern, and central Newfoundland. Time span: Thursday evening to Friday evening. Remarks: A mixture of rain and snow will begin either Thursday afternoon or evening before transitioning back to snow on Friday. The rainfall is not expected to be significant, but the combination of rain followed by snow and falling temperatures will likely lead to very slippery road conditions. Conditions will improve Friday afternoon or Friday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-18T05:30:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-17T13:31:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0568145572.2021

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A deep Pacific low in the Gulf of Alaska will track northward across the northern Alaskan Panhandle this evening and into Yukon overnight. Periods of snow will be heaviest this evening with the passage of the low. Total snowfall accumulations of near 20 cm are expected by midnight tonight. In addition, strong south winds gusting to 70 km/h will develop tonight and give widespread blowing snow and poor visibility. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-18T04:43:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-17T12:44:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3468066849.2021
Area: South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall and wind expected followed by potentially significant snowfall Thursday night and Friday. Total rainfall amounts: 30 to 50 mm. Potential snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: southerly between 80 and 100 km/h. Locations: the Burin and Bonavista peninsulas, as well as the Clarenville area. Time span: Thursday evening to Friday evening. Remarks: Rain will begin Thursday evening and become heavy at times on Friday. Strong southerly winds will accompany the rain, combining with temperatures well above freezing to cause considerable snow melt. If possible, storm drains should be cleared before Thursday night, as a combination of rain, snow melt, and runoff will likely lead to minor flooding in areas where pooling water cannot drain properly. Rain will change to potentially significant snow Friday evening with a period of freezing rain or ice pellets possible during the transition. Note that as temperatures fall below freezing Friday night, conditions will likely become quite icy. Conditions will improve overnight Friday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-18T05:31:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-17T13:32:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1701949026.2021
Area: Burin Peninsula, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada
